articles.title: Extreme cold warning returns Tuesday night for the Red Deer area
articles.author: Red Deer Advocate Staff
articles.summary: Extreme cold warning will be in effect starting 8 p.m. Tuesday and continuing into Wednesday morning for Red Deer. Wind chill values will moderate through daytime hours, but could return overnight Wednesday and Thursday morning for parts of Alberta. Frostbite can develop within minutes on exposed skin, especially with wind chill.

articles.title: Heat warnings in place for Adelaide, Hobart and Melbourne
articles.summary: Adelaide is forecast to reach 43 degrees on Wednesday. Melbourne is set for 34 degrees and Hobart is expected to reach 33 degrees. All three states are under a heatwave warning due to the high temperatures.   Â      in Melbourne.

articles.title: Axa XL supports environmental project in Sierra Leone
articles.author: Duncan Hall
articles.summary: Bermudian-based Axa XL is providing a grant of $1.2 million to Save the Children for a five-year initiative to mitigate the impact of climate change across coastal ecosystems in Sierra Leone. Sierra Leone has one of the lowest CO2 emissions per capita in the world. Its coastal areas are already experiencing rising seas and more extreme weather events. The community-led initiative will increase people's food and water security, support education and local enterprise and enhance the conservation and restoration of 1,500 hectares of mangrove ecosystems.

articles.title: What can we do to better understand our climate?
articles.summary: Dr. Kerry Cook talks about the second edition of her book "Climate Dynamics" at Listen Like a Local in Park City & Heber City Summit & Wasatch counties, Utah. The University of Texas at Austin professor teaches graduate Atmosphere and Ocean Dynamics courses and Global Warming courses.

articles.title: Parts of California, including San Diego County, are sinking: study
articles.author: Rhea Caoile
articles.summary: Land all along the California coast is shifting up and down due to natural and human-caused factors, according to a new case study led by a team at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory at the California Institute of Technology. The Central Valley and along the coast were the most impacted. Sea levels in California are expected to rise up to 14.5 inches by 2050.

articles.title: Aspen Institute climate conference relocates to Chicago
articles.author: Chicago Sun-Times
articles.summary: Aspen Ideas: Climate is relocating to Chicago this summer. It has been held in Miami Beach, Florida, for the past three years. It will take place in Chicago on July on July 25th. It addresses climate change, its effects and possible solutions.

articles.title: B.C. snowpack significantly lower than normal
articles.author: John Arendt
articles.summary: As of Feb. 1, the provincial snowpack was 72 per cent of normal. The Liard basin was the only part of the province to record a snowpack level higher than normal. La Niña weather conditions are expected to continue through the February to April period.

articles.title: From Augusta: From erosion to action
articles.author: Stacy Brenner
articles.summary: Stacy Brenner supports LD 1, An Act to Increase Storm Preparedness and Resilience for Maine's Communities, Homes and Infrastructure. The bill will have its public hearing on Feb. 11. Brenner encourages all Mainers to engage with the updated climate action plan.

articles.title: Trump's ‘America first' policy causes chaos
articles.author: B K Singh
articles.summary: Donald Trump has withdrawn the US from the Paris Climate Accord. At least 335 human deaths were attributed to Hurricane Beryl and Hurricane Milton. The Los Angeles fire killed at least 25 persons, damaged more than 15,000 structures and ravaged more than 200 square km area. La Nina arrived and pushed the storm back to the northern part of the US. Trump wants Canada to become the 51st state of the USA and wants to take over the Panama Canal from Panama and purchase Greenland from Denmark. The process of deportation of illegal immigrants has started in a big way.

articles.title: Why Australia should support a global right to free education
articles.author: Daniela Gavshon
articles.summary: Kids across Australia are getting ready for the new school term. Millions of children around the world won't be as fortunate to pass through the school gates this year, as they will not be able to go to school at all this year.

articles.title: Moa extinction: Human colonization sealed fate of New Zealand's giants, study shows
articles.author: Lauren Sydoruk
articles.summary: New research shows that human colonization and hunting contributed to the extinction of New Zealand's giant flightless bird, the moa. The research team used fossils and detailed computer modeling to reconstruct how six species of moa disappeared and whether their extinctions were avoidable.

articles.title: US was cold but world just lived through planet's hottest January on record
articles.author: Mark Collins
articles.summary: January 2025 was the warmest on record when considering the global average. It was the United States' coldest January since 1988 with an average of 29.23°F. The severe cold in the U.S. was caused by a polar vortex bringing frigid air from the Arctic. The overall warming trend is driven primarily by greenhouse gas emissions and warm ocean waters.

articles.title: Rep. Buddy Carter wants to rename Greenland
articles.author: WSBTV.com News Staff
articles.summary: Buddy Carter has introduced a bill to rename Greenland to 'Red, White and Blueland Act of 2025'. President Donald Trump signed a bill renaming Gulf of Mexico as the Gulf of America. All federal documents and maps would have to be updated to reflect the name change within 180 days if approved.

articles.title: Small Craft Warning and High Surf Advisory issued for the island
articles.author: Nationnews Desk
articles.summary: The Barbados Meteorological Services has issued a Small Craft Warning and High Surf Advisory for the island due to above-normal swell heights. The advisory was issued today, February 11, 2025 and will be updated at noon on Thursday, February 13. The situation is expected to peak between Thursday and Friday.

articles.title: Farmers in St. Mary's County Eligible for Federal Drought Aid
articles.author: David M. Higgins II
articles.summary: St. Mary's County, Anne Arundel, Baltimore, Calvert, Charles, Dorchester, Harford, and Prince George's counties were declared a primary natural disaster area due to drought and heat. The designation also includes counties across Maryland, Virginia, Pennsylvania, Delaware, and the District of Columbia. Farmers can apply for emergency loans through the USDA Farm Service Agency. The deadline to apply is September 15, 2025.

articles.title: Local angler Kate Shelton weighs in on the great shark debate
articles.author: Columnist Kate Shelton
articles.summary: There is an escalating shark population on the Mid North Coast. This is a disturbing trend that needs to be addressed immediately.    - the situation is not good for the health of the ecosystem and the local people. The situation is a problem for all of us.

articles.title: The Hypocrisy Of The Global North In Climate Change
articles.summary: The global North built its prosperity on decades of unchecked industrialization. Today the global South is struggling to develop. The same nations responsible for the crisis now dictate the rules for the global south.    - The Global North is responsible for polluting ecosystems without accountability.

articles.title: Climate wipeout looms for top surf spots without action
articles.summary: Griffith University study claims beach health will deteriorate further due to climate change. It focuses on popular eastern "point breaks" along headlands, favoured for their long, consistent rides but vulnerable to sea level rise. Margaret River's Main Break, Noosa Heads, Burleigh Heads, Byron Bay's The Pass, Lennox Head, Angourie and North Narrabeen in NSW, and Bells Beach in Victoria were included in the review.

articles.title: Climate wipeout looms for top surf spots without action
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Ms Curley is concerned about the surf ban affecting the 10 per cent of Australians who surf. It also impacts just your mum and dad being there with your child for a swim, as well as your parents and grandparents who might be in the water with their children.

articles.title: Climate wipeout looms for top surf spots without action
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: In the future surfers could face lacklustre swells, fewer surfable days and harmful algal blooms at a number of iconic eastern breaks due to climate change, according to the Griffith University study commissioned by the Surfrider Foundation Australia. It follows the release of two major global studies suggesting the planet will cross the 1.5C of warming, the threshold dictated in the Paris climate pact, earlier than expected. The literature review focuses on popular "point breaks" along headlands favoured for their long rides but vulnerable to sea level rise.

articles.title: Greater Egypt Regional Planning and Development Commission to hold presentation Feb. 13
articles.author: Alexis-Barrett
articles.summary: At 7 p.m. on February 13, Neil Vincent, Kelsey Bowe and Tyler Carpenter of the Greater Egypt Regional Planning and Development Commission will present on the Carbondale Urban Heat Island Pilot Study. According to the Shawnee Group of the Sierra Club, urban environments generate more heat.

articles.title: What 80 degrees in February does to Georgia blueberries. Major fruit, crops at risk
articles.author: Juliet
articles.summary: It was 80 degrees in Columbus, Georgia on Saturday, almost breaking the record of 81 degrees set in 1927. Blueberries are one of Georgia's biggest agriculture products and blueberry growers are worried about the 2025 season because of the warm weather. The oceans are running a few degrees above normal in the Gulf of Mexico.

articles.title: African Development Bank's Climate Action Window Channels $31m to Boost Climate Resilience in Four Countries
articles.summary: The Board of Directors of the African Development Bank Group has approved over $31 million in funding under its African Climate Action Window to strengthen climate resilience in Sierra Leone, South Sudan, Djibouti, and Madagascar. Forty-one pioneering climate adaptation projects valued at $321.75 million have been selected in the initial funding wave.

articles.title: Record hot January despite cooling La Nina effect
articles.author: Bitwize
articles.summary: January was the world's warmest January on record, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service. It was 1.75 degrees Celsius (3.15 degrees Fahrenheit) hotter than pre-industrial times. It comes after historic temperature highs in 2023 and 2024. 2024 was the hottest year on record. Global average temperature rise has reached 1.3 degrees Celsius.

articles.title: Paul Smith's helps tackle Climate Change: Community Listening Sessions Underway
articles.author: Gene Morse
articles.summary: The Adirondack Climate Outreach & Resilience Network is holding community listening sessions to address the growing impacts of climate change in the Adirongack-North Country region. The network spans the 14-county region of Northern New York State. The information collected will be used to develop a Rural Resilient Roadmap and be shared with Federal & State agencies and philanthropic organizations.

articles.title: Paul Smith's helps tackle Climate Change: Community Listening Sessions Underway
articles.author: Gene Morse
articles.summary: Paul Smith's College, in partnership with The Wild Center, Adirondack Research Consortium and community partners announced they are continuing efforts to hold community listening sessions to address the growing impacts of climate change. The network spans the 14-county region of Northern New York State and will be used to develop a Rural Resilience Roadmap.

articles.title: Climate change can mean fewer birds in our Northeast Ohio yards. Here's how to help.
articles.author: Lois Rose
articles.summary: There are fewer birds in our yards and parks due to climate change. Bird loss has been staggering since 1970. Forests have lost 1 billion birds. Grassland populations have decreased by more than half. Domestic cats kill an estimated 1.3-4 billion birds each year. City lights can confuse migrating birds.

articles.title: The Paris Agreement is Dead... So Where Are the Consequences?
articles.author: Dr. Matthew Wielicki
articles.summary: Earth has spent 12 months above the 1.5°C threshold, but there's no evidence of catastrophic consequences. The "global temperature" is a construct, not a physical reality. The Paris Agreement was built upon this flawed premise. It weaponized a statistical construct to drive political decisions that impact energy, economics and global policy.

articles.title: January 2025 was warmest on record as climate change ‘overwhelms' La Niña's cooling
articles.author: SAT Articles
articles.summary: January 2025 was the warmest January on record, surpassing the previous record set by January 2024. The global average surface air temperature for the month reached 1.75° Celsius (3.15° F) The most dramatic variation was up to 6°C (10.8°F) in northern Canada, Russia and the Scandinavian countries.

articles.title: I was shocked to find countryside of West Lothian covered in concrete
articles.author: Readers
articles.summary: In the last 150 years the planet's human population has increased from around 1.5 billion to around 8 billion. We use 1.4 times what the planet can produce every year and we are digging into reserves laid down millions of years ago. Liz Smith is a rural MSP. Outdoor education in primary schools has been encouraged by the Scottish Government. Children who have difficulty engaging in the classroom benefit from outdoor activities.

articles.title: Paris climate target nearer than thought as Earth heats faster
articles.author: Andrew Freedman
articles.summary: The Paris Agreement's 1.5°C aspirational target for global warming is largely symbolic. January marked the 18th month in a 19-month stretch in which each month has exceeded the threshold. Experts say it's premature to conclude that the target has been exceeded.

articles.title: Gulf of Mexico Renamed to ‘Gulf of America' by Google Maps for US Users
articles.author: Coming Soon
articles.summary: Google recently renamed the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America on their Google Maps application. This development has surprised many people and they are now curious about all the details about the renaming of the area on Google Maps. The information is available on Google's official website.

articles.title: Shaping Conditions for Fair, Equitable and Enduring Climate Finance
articles.summary: COP 29 concluded with a disappointing New Collective Quantified Goal on Climate Finance (NCQG), leaving developing nations at risk of being left behind. The Baku to Belem Roadmap has been developed to address the climate finance gap. The framework will be finalized at COP30 in Brazil.

articles.title: EU $4M Aid Tackles Horn of Africa Hunger Crisis
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: EU funding supports 450,000 vulnerable people in Horn of Africa. Project aims to reduce climate and conflict impact. UN and humanitarian agencies will work together on the project. The Horn is one of the world's poorest regions with 57 million people living in extreme poverty. 23 million people across Ethiopia, Kenya and Somalia are food insecure.

articles.title: From Vision to Action: UN Contributions to the Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for SIDS
articles.summary: Small Island Developing States (SIDS) in the Caribbean are vulnerable to climate change, environmental degradation, and economic instability. The Antigua and Barbuda Agenda for SIDS (ABAS) offers a transformative vision for addressing these challenges, emphasizing resilience-building, sustainable development, and social equity as cornerstones for a secure and prosperous future. Between 2000 and 2022, Caribbean SIDS suffered 91% of economic losses from tropical storms.

articles.title: Spain and WFP partner to strengthen resilience of indigenous women in the Philippines' Bangsamoro region
articles.author: Journal Online
articles.summary: The Spanish Agency for International Development Cooperation (AECID) contributed $780,000 to a project to boost the climate resilience of indigenous women in the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM). The project will reach 28,000 people from indigenous and rural communities. It also aims to promote leadership opportunities for women and strengthen their skills for adapting to climate change.

articles.title: World Likely to Breach 1.5-Degree Target, Research Finds
articles.author: Yale Environment 360
articles.summary: Last year was the first year to measure roughly 1.5 degrees warmer than the preindustrial era, but the world has not yet surpassed the Paris Agreement's target of limiting warming to one degree over the next 20 years. New research shows the world will probably exceed this threshold in the near future.

articles.title: Scientists warn world is entering new phase of global warming
articles.summary: Last year's record-breaking temperatures could be a sign that the world is entering a new era of global warming. The Paris Agreement threshold of 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels is a marker of risk for people and nature. Most countries missed a deadline to submit emissions-cutting plans for the decade ahead that align with the Paris goal.

articles.title: Arctic air threatens Plant City's 13,000-acre strawberry crop ahead of Valentine's Day harvest
articles.summary: Plant City-Dover, Florida, is the "Winter Strawberry Capital of the Nation". The region has over 13,000 acres of strawberries and contributes nearly 15% to the national production. Recent Arctic air surges have posed risks to these crops. Matt Parke, managing 300 acres in Plant City, has implemented measures to shield his strawberries from frost.

articles.title: Five ways that illustrations can tell climate justice stories
articles.author: Andi Misbahul Pratiwi
articles.summary: Puspita Bahari's PhD research involved fieldwork in three coastal villages in Demak, Central Java, Indonesia. She has produced an illustrated book, Tidal Floods: Women, Fisheries, and Climate Crisis in Indonesia (2024), about the effects of climate change on Indonesian fisherwomen. She explains how illustrations can be used to tell climate justice stories.

articles.title: Minnesota's ducks don't want to be snowbirds anymore
articles.author: Nick Halter
articles.summary: Nick is surprised to see ducks in Minnesota in minus 20 degrees in the winter. Ducks are choosing not to migrate due to evolution and climate change. Audubon Society has been conducting an annual bird count around Christmas for 124 years. Minnesota robins and Canadian geese are migrating less.

articles.title: B.C. snowpack significantly lower than normal
articles.author: John Arendt
articles.summary: As of Feb. 1, the provincial snowpack was 72 per cent of normal. The Liard basin was the only part of the province to record a snowpack level higher than normal. La Niña weather conditions are expected to continue through the February to April period.

articles.title: Tibetan tree rings link climate stress to Chinese dynastic turmoil: study
articles.author: The Standard
articles.summary: Last year was the hottest on record both globally and in China. Last year's extreme weather events wreaked havoc worldwide and caused $310 billion in economic losses. The rise and fall of several Chinese dynasties coincided with the timing of significant shifts towards arid conditions.

articles.title: Tell it to SunStar: Climate adaptation for LGUs: One size does not fit all
articles.author: Rachel Anne
articles.summary: Rachel Anne Herrera is a commissioner of the Climate Change Commission. National climate resilience efforts need to be tailored to meet the needs of individual communities, she says. She is calling for a whole-of-country approach to climate change resilience efforts.

articles.title: Born too late? Climate change is delaying childbirth globally
articles.author: India Today
articles.summary: Born too late. Climate change is delaying childbirth globally, according to UNICEF.    "There is a risk of being born too late due to climate change.  "   "  "It's a matter of when, not if."

articles.title: What the Arctic will look like by 2100 if climate change continues, according to science
articles.author: Sophie Thompson
articles.summary: In 2024, global air temperatures surpassed 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels for the first time. The Arctic is warming at four times the rate of the rest of the planet. Even if we manage to keep temperatures below 2.7 degrees, the Arctic region will still face a number of summer months with no ice left in the sea, surface-level permafrost will decrease by 50 per cent and sea levels will rise faster.

articles.title: This is what the Arctic will look like by 2100 - and yes, it should scare you
articles.author: Sophie Thompson
articles.summary: In 2024, global air temperatures surpassed 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels for the first time. The Arctic is warming at four times the rate of the rest of the planet. Even if we manage to keep temperatures below 2.7 degrees, the Arctic region will still face a number of summer months with no ice left in the sea, surface-level permafrost will decrease by 50 per cent and sea levels will rise faster.

articles.title: Scientists make ominous discovery about volcanoes beneath Antarctic ice sheet
articles.author: Chloe Bryant
articles.summary: Melting ice sheets in the Arctic and Antarctic have a huge impact on our planet. The Earth depends on ice sheets to reflect sunlight back into space to regulate temperature and create a stable climate. As ice melts, less weight bears down on the Earth's crust, causing it to shift upward. This can trigger explosive volcanic eruptions in one of Earth's most significant volcanic areas.

articles.title: Cormorants increasingly spending winters off Estonia's coasts
articles.author: Marko Mägi
articles.summary: Cormorants migrate south for the winter to ice-free fishing grounds. The cormorant population has grown significantly across Europe and in Estonia. Modern tracking technology is also used to track their migration routes and wintering grounds. Cormorants from a single breeding ground tend to disperse across multiple wintering locations, so monitoring a breeding population won't resolve the problem.

articles.title: Brazil has seen a 460% increase in climate-related disasters since the 1990s
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: From 1991 through 2023, each rise of 0.1°C in the average global air temperature led to 360 new climate-related disasters. The relationship between rising global temperatures and the number of such disasters is directly proportional. 2024 will be the hottest year in history.

articles.title: The real reason Greenland is important to Florida
articles.author: Daniel Reifsnyder
articles.summary: Ice melt in Greenland is already a major factor in the sea level rise now impacting the Florida coastline. Sen. Ted Cruz will convene a hearing on Feb. 12 to discuss and support President Trump's ill-advised ambitions to exploit Greenland. The U.S. and other developed countries are largely responsible for the climate pollution causing Greenland's glaciers to melt.

articles.title: Urgent Call to Address Silent Health Crisis of Heat
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Australian Medical Association is meeting in Canberra today to discuss the health impacts of climate change and rising temperatures on human health. 2024 will be the hottest year on record and the first calendar year in which the average global temperature was more than 1.5 degrees Celsius warmer than pre-industrial times. AMA was one of the first organisations to take a stand on climate change more than 20 years ago.

articles.title: As sea levels rise, Malay descendants in Cocos Islands face uncertainty
articles.author: Afp
articles.summary: The Cocos Islands are threatened by coastal erosion and rising sea levels driven by climate change. The government proposes to relocate residents in the next 10 to 50 years. Many of the 600 residents of Cocos Island are descendants of Malay workers brought to the islands to work in the coconut plantations in the 1830s.

articles.title: Have we already breached the 1.5°C global warming target?
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: The climate goals set by the Paris Agreement are based on the long-term average temperature. One year of high temperatures might be a sign that the 1.5°C threshold has already been reached, as one year of such high temperatures is a sign of climate change.

articles.title: Extreme Cold Warning issued February 11 at 2:18AM MST until February 12 at 10:00AM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
articles.author: National Weather Service
articles.summary: There is an Extreme Cold Warning for Arco/Mud Lake Desert and Upper Snake River Plain from 8 PM this evening to 10 AM MST Wednesday. There is a second Extreme Cold warning from 9 PM Wednesday to 10 am MST Thursday. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 30 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.

articles.title: Monash Expert Tackles Extreme Weather and Flood Risks
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Monash Business School's Green Lab will host their second roundtable on extreme weather events, flood risk and stormwater systems on 13 February. The roundtable will discuss and compare experience from Australia, the United States and Asia with leading academics and practitioners. It is intended to help navigate a pathway forward in the face of global temperature rise exceeding 2 degrees.

articles.title: Letter: Trump's denying world's pressing, true needs
articles.author: Sharon Cox
articles.summary: Donald Trump is a commander of lies, denials, revenge, self-interest, politically and personally motivated politician to the detriment of us all. He is fiddling while Rome burns. The future of our planet and all its inhabitants is in dire jeopardy.

articles.title: AfDB Approves Over $31M to Boost Climate Resilience in Four African Nations
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Board of Directors of the African Development Bank Group has sanctioned over $31 million in funding to bolster climate resilience efforts in Sierra Leone, South Sudan, Djibouti, and Madagascar. This initiative is part of the Bank's broader objective to mobilize $4 billion by 2025 under the Africa Development Fund's framework. 41 climate adaptation projects, collectively valued at $321.75 million, were chosen in the initial funding round.

articles.title: SA braces for hottest day in five years
articles.summary: SA braces for hottest day in five years. The feature is currently unavailable, but we're working to restore it. Please try to try again later.  .      Â   yestoforeseeable future events.

articles.title: Price of some sunscreen products could go up
articles.summary: The Australian Tax Office updates its GST guidelines. The price of some sunscreen products could rise as a result of the update.      .   "The price of sunscreen products may rise as the Australian tax office updates its tax guidelines."

articles.title: Hot weather warning issued in South Australia as records expected to reach new highs
articles.summary: Temperatures are expected to reach 49 degrees Celsius in Oodnadatta on Wednesday. The Bureau of Meteorology has predicted temperatures will reach 43C in Adelaide. The total fire ban will come into effect at midnight tonight. A fire in the Mount Remarkable National Park has already burnt 4,600 hectares. A firefighter who suffered severe burns during the initial efforts to fight the blaze last week had surgery yesterday.

articles.title: Namibia's Drought Crisis: Building Resilience for Women and Girls
articles.summary: Namibia is facing one of its worst droughts in more than a hundred years. The drought has triggered widespread food insecurity, environmental degradation, health threats and rising unemployment. The UN mobilized resources through the UN Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) to tackle the crisis. UNICEF provides lifesaving support to breastfeeding mothers and children impacted by the drought emergency. UNFPA provides protection initiatives, including family planning and counseling services.

articles.title: Australia's Macquarie joins major banks in exiting global climate coalition
articles.author: Adwitiya Srivastava
articles.summary: Macquarie Group is leaving the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA), a UN-sponsored initiative to encourage financial institutions to limit the effects of climate change and push toward achieving net-zero emissions. Trump's presidential victory and his subsequent decisions to pull out from the Paris Agreement and the UN Green Climate Fund have triggered an exodus from the NZBA, which has 134 members in 44 countries.

articles.title: UN Estimates More Than 17 Million Yemenis Will Face Acute Food Insecurity in 2025
articles.author: Waddah Aljaleel
articles.summary: 17.1 million people in Yemen will suffer from acute food insecurity this year. The majority of those affected are located in Houthi-controlled areas. This year's humanitarian response plan aims to reach 12 million of the most vulnerable people through emergency food assistance and livelihood support.

articles.title: Climate change means Australia has entered the ‘age of the engineer'
articles.author: Edmund Tadros
articles.summary: Louise Adams is the incoming head of engineering consulting firm Aurecon. She will become chief executive in July. She says more engineers are needed as a result of extreme weather caused by climate change. There have already been flash floods in Queensland and NSW and heatwaves across the heart of Australia during the summer months.

articles.title: ‘Virtually certain' Earth has already breached 1.5-degree warming threshold
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: last year's record-breaking temperatures could be a sign that the world was entering a new era of global warming.    for more information on global warming at www.globallywarming.org.  For more information about global warming, go to: Global Warming.

articles.title: Earth's Crucial Turning Point: Crossing the 1.5°C Threshold
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Earth's average temperature in 2024 was 1.6°C above pre-industrial levels. Global warming trend indicates Earth's possible entrance into a sustained period of high temperatures. This development highlights the urgency for global measures to achieve net-zero emissions.

articles.title: Earth Surpasses 1.5°C Warming, Two Studies Reveal
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Earth is crossing the threshold of 1.5°C of global warming, according to two major global studies. Under the Paris Agreement on climate change, humanity is seeking to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and keep planetary heating to no more than one degree Celsius above the pre-industrial average. Last year was the hottest on record. The global average temperature in 2024 was about 1.6°C above the average temperatures in the late-19th century.

articles.title: ‘Virtually certain' Earth has already breached 1.5-degree warming threshold
articles.author: Bloomberg
articles.summary: The Paris Agreement was signed in 2015. 196 countries agreed to rein in greenhouse gas emissions to keep the global average temperature increase to 'well below' 2 degrees. New analyses showed the world would surpass the latter. In 2024, global temperatures reached 1.5 degrees for the entire year for the first time in recorded history.

articles.title: 'The quality of life here is impeccable': why Londoners are moving to Australia
articles.author: India Block
articles.summary: There are 46,000 Brits living in Australia on temporary visas as of December 2024, up from 3,600 in December 2021. Simi is a junior doctor who moved to Melbourne in January of 2024. Tabitha moved to Sydney in 2019.

articles.title: VIDEO: Residents in WA's northwest prepare for a potential tropical cyclone
articles.author: Charlie Mills
articles.summary: Travellers in the Pilbara town of Port Hedland are preparing to move south to avoid the worst of a tropical low forecast to develop into a cyclone tomorrow. The low is expected to form into a tropical cyclone by tomorrow morning. The weather is not expected to be very bad.

articles.title: Antarctic Report Released
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories has tabled its report, Australia's Antarctic Territory: Report on the Inquiry into the Importance of Antarctica to Australia's National Interests. Committee Chair, Alicia Payne MP, said it is important that Australia continues to invest in world leading research and support Antarctic science. Committee has made 13 recommendations relating to the relationship with the Antarctic Treaty System, supporting conservation and scientific research, and the beneficial position of Hobart as an Antarctic Gateway.

articles.title: New project to uncover a century of change at Poole Harbour
articles.author: Deb Gayen
articles.summary: Coasts in Mind project will assess the impact of climate change on the country's most vulnerable coastlines. The project was made possible by a grant of £2,334,235 from the National Lottery Heritage Fund. The current phase of the project will take place over the course of three years. It is hoped the archive will be widened to include other affected coastal communities across the UK.

articles.title: It Has Been Over Five Years Since The Guardian Officially Introduced Its Climate Change PsyOp:  An In-Depth Look At How it Is Going
articles.author: Rhonda
articles.summary: The Guardian changed its house style guide to introduce terms that more accurately describe the environmental crises facing the world. The preferred terms for The Guardian are 'climate emergency, crisis, or breakdown' and 'global heating' instead of 'climate change'. The change reflected the urgency of the situation and aimed to better convey the seriousness of global heating. The change is not fair, unbiased, objective and neutral journalism that serves as a watchdog on government and those who wish to be in power.

articles.title: Fact check: Have emissions risen under the Albanese government?
articles.author: Mike Foley
articles.summary: In the year to September, Australia generated 441 million tonnes of greenhouse gases, which was 1.2 million tonnes more than the previous year. This equates to a rise of 0.3 per cent. The Albanese government has pledged to cut Australia's emissions 43 per cent by 2030 by swapping clean energy for fossil fuels.

articles.title: Fact check: Have emissions risen under the Albanese government?
articles.author: Mike Foley
articles.summary: In the year to September, Australia generated 441 million tonnes of greenhouse gases, which was 1.2 million tonnes more than the previous year. This equates to a rise of 0.3 per cent on the previous 12 months. Australia's annual emissions levels have remained virtually unchanged since now and June 2022.

articles.title: Community Science: Great Backyard Bird Count
articles.summary: This year's Great Backyard Bird Count is February 14-17. Library staff will be at Grand Caribe Shoreline park on Sunday from 9:30 am to 1 pm. SD Bird Alliance will provide a scope that participants can use to get better views of birds. Teens can earn volunteer hours for their participation.

articles.title: Climate change is weakening extreme cold events, study finds
articles.author: Climate
articles.summary: Human-induced climate change is making extreme cold events less severe, according to a new joint study by Chinese and U.S. researchers. Extreme cold waves still occur, but their intensity and frequency have decreased due to global warming. Such events are projected to become even rarer and milder by the end of the century.

articles.title: Uncharted Warming
articles.author: SNS
articles.summary: The earth has just witnessed its hottest January on record, defying expectations. This is despite the shift from an El Niño to a developing La Niña. The scale of warming over the past two years has exceeded projections by 0.2°C. The urgency of reducing greenhouse gas emissions has never been greater.

articles.title: HEDA urges governors to utilise SCP to boost economic activities, others
articles.author: Blueprint
articles.summary: The Human and Environmental Development Agenda (HEDA Resource Centre) urges governors to take advantage of the 2025 Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) to boost their economic resilience and sustainability. HEDA urges the governors to utilise SCP to boost economic activities.

articles.title: A mixed bag: Views on immigration in Australia
articles.author: Post-Courier Contributor
articles.summary: People in Australia overestimate net migration by 59% compared to actual figures. People in rural areas tend to overestimate the share of migrants from the Pacific. Most people in Australia do not support a reduction in international students. People are less hostile to temporary migrants than to permanent migrants.

articles.title: Women in Climate series: Gender gap
articles.author: The National
articles.summary: This series is sponsored by GIB AM. Climate change affects all of us equally, but women are disproportionately affected by it, particularly those in marginalised communities.    - GIB am.  - Climate Change is a problem for all people, but especially for women.

articles.title: Binh Dinh addresses fishing community concerns in boat parking relocation
articles.author: SGGP
articles.summary: Binh Dinh Province wants to relocate over 600 fishing vessels from Quy Nhon City to De Gi Port in Phu Cat District. Many people are concerned about the impact on livelihoods. The draft boat relocation support policy requires an estimated VND200- VND9 billion.

articles.title: Farmers fear they are unprepared and unsupported to deal with climate change
articles.author: Caroline O'Doherty
articles.summary: More than 200 farmers took part in a study commissioned by the Climate Change Advisory Council and Teagasc. They are seeing the imprint of climate change in extreme weather and unreliable seasons that made planning work and carrying it out more difficult.    Today at 21:30 farmers will discuss the study.

articles.title: Adelaide weather: Code red alert issued for South Australia amid heatwave
articles.author: Brett Lackey
articles.summary: Oak Valley in southern Australia will reach 48 ° C, while the nulllarbor is looking at a top of 47 ° C. The minimum temperatures during the night will be twenty years mediated and high. The alert is designed to warn people who are vulnerable to climatic conditions, such as homeless or elderly people.

articles.title: It's ‘virtually certain' the world has already breached 1.5 C
articles.author: Bloomberg
articles.summary: In 2024, global temperatures reached 1.5 C for the entire year for the first time in recorded history. This January was the hottest on record despite the cooling influence of an emerging La Nina. The Paris Agreement was inked in 2015. 196 countries agreed to rein in greenhouse gas emissions to keep the global average temperature increase to "well below" 2 C and ideally cap it at 1:5 C. New analyses show the world will surpass the latter.

articles.title: BREAKING NEWS Adelaide weather: Code red alert issued for South Australia amid heatwave
articles.author: HARRISON CHRISTIAN
articles.summary: Oak Valley in South Australia will hit 48C, while the Nullarbor is looking at a top of 47C. The temperatures are the hottest seen at this time of year in the region since 2007. Adelaide's temperature is expected to soar past 39C. Overnight temperatures will be in the mid to high twenties.

articles.title: Sheep migrate over frozen lake in China's Xizang
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Before the spring thaw, villagers in China's Xizang guide sheep across the icy Puma Yumco Lake from its grassy mid-lake island. This migration has continued for thousands of years and marks the arrival of spring for local people.

articles.title: Tibetan tree rings highlight link between climate change and fall of major Chinese dynasties
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: Study tracking climate patterns across thousands of years found that periods of lower rainfall coincided with some major political upheavals in the past, as well as periods of higher rainfall during which there was less political upheaval.      .   in the recent past.

articles.title: World may have entered era of 1.5C warming, scientists say
articles.author: Maleeha Lodhi
articles.summary: Last year's record-breaking temperatures could be a sign that the world is entering a new era of global warming. The Paris Agreement threshold of 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels is a marker of risk for people and nature. A single year above the limit does not mark a breach of the Paris deal.

articles.title: Experts in Gwadar discuss climate change challenges
articles.author: Behram Baloch
articles.summary: The three-day seminar on climate change in Gwadar concluded on Sunday. Participants were taken on a field trip to observe affected areas of the city, wetlands, and drainage issues. The GDA reaffirmed its commitment to continue research and take practical measures to face the climate change challenge.

articles.title: Experts discuss climate change challenges
articles.author: Behram Baloch
articles.summary: The three-day seminar on climate change in Gwadar concluded on Sunday. Participants were taken on a field trip to observe affected areas of the city, wetlands, and drainage issues. The GDA reaffirmed its commitment to continue research and take practical measures to face the climate change challenge.

articles.title: Streaking No. 8 Texas A&M welcomes skidding Georgia
articles.summary: There will be 50% chance of rain showers overnight in Griffin, GA. The weather is going to get worse overnight. The rain will thaw out in the morning and give way to dry weather in the afternoon. The temperature will drop to 44F. Winds will be around 5 to 10 mph.

articles.title: Two Major Studies Agree Earth Is Entering Frightening New Climate Phase
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year on record and the first to breach the 1.5°C global warming threshold for the Paris Agreement on climate change. Global average temperature in 2024 was about 1.6°C above the pre-industrial average, before humans started burning fossil fuels at large scale.

articles.title: Report Exposes Hardships for Aussie Migrant Meat Workers
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Report launched today – Meat the reality: unpacking the exploitation of PALM scheme workers in Australia's meat industry. It gives voice to the experiences of Pacific Island workers in the industry who feel trapped and exploited. Mirage News does not take institutional positions or sides and all views, positions and conclusions expressed herein are solely those of the author(s).

articles.title: Climate change weakening extreme cold events: study
articles.author: 董森河
articles.summary: Study by Chinese and US researchers found that human-induced climate change is reducing the severity of extreme cold events. The research focused on the severe cold wave that hit eastern China in December 2023. It found that unusual large-scale atmospheric circulation patterns were the primary drivers of the event, accounting for 83 percent of its intensity.

articles.title: Most animals have their own version of tree rings – here's how we biologists use ...
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Narwhal tusks reveal how they're affected by declining Arctic ice. Saifullahphtographer has a natural fascination with time. He explains how landscapes have been carved over millennia, how our bodies grow and sag with age, and how the stars traverse the sky each night.

articles.title: Five ways that illustrations can tell climate justice stories
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Climate change is often communicated through scientific reports, statistics and policy discussions. However, these technical approaches can be inaccessible to the public, failing to capture the experiences of those most affected. Climate narratives need to be structured as stories that involve emotional engagement and involve people's participation.

articles.title: Tibetan tree rings link climate stress to Chinese dynastic turmoil: study
articles.author: Hong Kong Standard
articles.summary: Last year was the hottest on record both globally and in China. More arid periods coincided with ages of dynastic turmoil in China, according to a study tracking rainfall patterns over thousands of years. There is a historical link between climate stress and social unrest.

articles.title: Thousands of birds dead due to avian influenza at the Great Salt Lake
articles.author: Ogden Standard Examiner
articles.summary: Millions of eared grebes gather on the Great Salt Lake on Tuesday, Dec. 20, 2016. The lake is a major destination for migrating birds from around North America. The eared Grebes are one of the last remaining species of grebes.

articles.title: Experts discuss climate change challenges
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Experts at a three-day seminar on climate change in Gwadar concluded on Sunday. They said immediate actions are needed for survival of the planet.      Â   y   for the survival of planet, according to experts.

articles.title: South Africa Strengthens Maritime Environmental Laws as Cape Route Traffic Surges Amid Red Sea Crisis
articles.author: g Captain
articles.summary: President Cyril Ramaphosa signed into law the Marine Pollution Amendment Bill. The move comes at a crucial time as ship traffic around the Cape of Good Hope has increased due to the ongoing Red Sea crisis. The bill enhances South Africa's maritime environmental protection measures.

articles.title: Farmers fear they are unprepared and unsupported to deal with climate change
articles.author: Irish Independent
articles.summary: Climate change is costing farmers time and money and adding to their stress, according to a new report. It is also costing farmers a lot of money and aggravating their health and stress, it adds to their workloads.    iReport.com:

articles.title: Don't look up: is an asteroid heading for Earth?
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: A 100-metre-wide asteroid has triggered global planetary defence procedures for the first time. Ian Sample hears from Ian Sample to find out what happens now and how worried we should be. Ian hears from him to explain the current situation and discuss the future.

articles.title: Residents tell of continuing chaos post Storm Éowyn
articles.author: Irish Independent
articles.summary: the long tail of Storm Éowyn damage continues to be felt in communities, as well as in the affected areas.   for more information on the storm damage.  for the affected communities,  for eowyn's damage and for the community.

articles.title: Scientists identify heat-resistant kelp strain
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Kelp is being negatively impacted by climate change. Warming ocean temperatures have led to shorter growing and harvesting seasons for sugar kelp, one of the most important kelp species.       "Kelps are a very important part of the marine ecosystem.

articles.title: Australia at a Crossroads: Why Jews Are Discussing a Plan B
articles.author: The Algemeiner
articles.summary: Opinion Arsonists damaged the Adass Israel Synagogue in Melbourne, Australia, on Dec. 6, 2024. There was a time when leaving Australia never crossed my mind. Having an Israeli wife and being a passionate Zionist, I always considered leaving Australia.

articles.title: Seeding time nears: Key is to have good seed-to-soil contact through precison placement
articles.author: The Daily Record
articles.summary: This winter has felt a little more like a traditional winter season. It has been a while since I remember a year where the ground was covered in snow for the majority of January. As we have moved into early February, we are seeing the expected large temperature swings. I would prefer for it to get cold and stay cold.

articles.title: World may have entered era of 1.5C warming—scientists
articles.author: Manila Standard
articles.summary: Last year's record-breaking temperatures could be a sign that the world is entering a new era above 1.5C of global warming, scientists say. The Paris Agreement threshold of 1,5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels is a small-sounding number with big implications.

articles.title: Floods cause Malaysia's palm oil output to sink most in 9 years
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: Sarawak and Sabah are among the worst-hit states by recent heavy rains and floods. Sarawak is a top oil palm growing area.    Sarwak is the state with the highest number of oil palm farmers.

articles.title: Experts in Gwadar discuss climate change challenges
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Experts at a three-day seminar on climate change in Gwadar concluded on Sunday. They said immediate actions are needed for survival of the planet.      Â   y   for the survival of planet, according to experts.

articles.title: Global air travel surges while switch to clean jet fuel lags
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Global air travel surged to record levels last year. Airlines are consuming far less sustainable jet fuel than expected. Aviation contributes about 4% of human-induced warming to date. Airline industry claims that 10% is a target that probably won't be met by 2030.

articles.title: World may have entered era of 1.5C warming, scientists say
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Last year's record-breaking temperatures could be a sign that the world is entering a new era of global warming. The Paris Agreement threshold of 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels is a marker of risk, with more warming linked to worsening floods, heatwaves and storms, as well as gradual effects like sea level rise and species extinctions.

articles.title: Climate whiplash
articles.author: Engr Jan Nisar
articles.summary: Pakistan is a victim of hydro-climate whiplash: extreme shifts between excessive rainfall and prolonged drought. For every 1C rise in global temperature, the atmosphere can absorb 7% more water, leading to more intense rainfall events followed by extended dry spells. Pakistan must adopt an integrated approach to co-manage extreme rainfall and drought.

articles.title: Counties lagging behind in their contribution to Kenya's agriculture sector
articles.author: Hillary Bett
articles.summary: Agriculture is Kenya's economic backbone. Some counties contribute less due to factors like arid climates, poor infrastructure, and limited investment. Marsabit, Mandera, Wajir, and Isiolo struggle with harsh climatic conditions. Tana River and Garissa face frequent droughts. Nairobi has minimal agricultural activity. Lamu and Taita Taveta have untapped agricultural potential but face challenges like poor irrigation and market access. Turkana lacks adequate water resources for farming.

articles.title: Most nations miss deadline for new climate targets
articles.author: The Standard
articles.summary: Just 10 of nearly 200 countries required under the Paris Agreement to deliver fresh climate plans by yesterday did so on time, according to a UN database tracking the submissions. Each country is supposed to provide a steeper headline figure for cutting heat-trapping emissions by 2035 and a detailed blueprint for how to achieve this. Australia has proposed moving hundreds of residents from their island home within decades as sea levels rise.
